additionalTextInformation.text:
The portrait is a removable component of an epitaph:
The portrait shows the corpse of Hermann Bonnus, the first superintendent of Lübeck [and it was executed for the superintendent’s epitaph]. After his death on the 12th of February 1548 he was laid out for three days in his burial place in the Sängerkapelle of the Marienkirche. The epitaph consists of a simple rectangular panel into which the framed portrait was inserted at the top. The deceased’s date of death is located below and beside it an inscription consisting of five distichs lists the superintendent’s merits.
[Exhib. Cat. Lübeck 2015, 367]

pageContext.description:
The deceased is laid out and is depicted from the right in three quarter profile. His facial features are relaxed, his eyes are closed and his hair and beard are accurately clipped. He is wearing a pleated shirt, his body is covered. The head rests on a high pillow with a yellow cloth cover. In front a diamond-pattern is visible on a light red ground. The bier stands in a room. There is a gilded pillar with a classical capital behind the head of the deceased, while the rest of the room is obscured by a curtain. Above the head there is a shape redolent of a medallion, which may belong to a wall painting.
[Exhib. Cat. Lübeck 2015, 366f]
Since the conservation treatment some of the details can be reinterpreted: the pillow is in fact white, but the yellowed varnish made it appear yellow, the pillar is wooden rather than gilded, the classical capital appears to be a profile, the 'medallion on the wall' is probably a carving on a bedstead. 
[Conservation report, Maire Müller-Andrae von Butt, conservation treatment, 2015]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 39 x 51.5 x 1.5 cm
Dimensions of epitaph: 127 x 260 x 4.2 cm
[St. Annen-Museum, revised 2018]
pageContext.inscription:
At the request of the town council Lübeck¿s first superintendent Hermann Bonnus was portrayed for his epitaph while he was laid out in the Sängerkapelle of the Marienkirche in February 1548. 
The portrait got lost during the 19th century and was replaced in 1917 by this painting. This is a contemporary copy, but nothing is known about its creation. It was probably made for a family for private devotion [¿] 
[Exhib. Cat. Lübeck 2015, 367]
- 1757 sold from a pivate collection, Lübeck (the daughter Hilcke Bonnus)  
- 1835 recorded in the inventory of the Munciple library, Lübeck 
- from 1917 inserted in the Bonnus-Epitaph in the Marienkirche, Lübeck 
- transferred to the St. Annen-Museum at the end of 1947
[St. Annen-Museum, inventory sheet 1984]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis:
- the portrait is in rather bad condition
Support:
- the join in the original panel is open, and may have been the reason for the maroflage. The panel exhibits numerous splits in the direction of the grain. 
Paint layers:
- in some areas the the ground and paint layers have been lost, revealing the bare wood beneath, in total this loss amounts to about 35-40% of the original. Most of the losses were filled and covered by extensive overpaint in the past. The flesh paint has been partially cleaned.
During the recent conservation treatment many of these interventions were reverted, varnish layers and overpaint were thinned, and losses were reintegrated.

restorationSurveys.remarks:
about 1950 further conservatioon treatment 
[St. Annen-Museum, inventory sheet 1984]

restorationSurveys.overallAnalysis: comprehensive conservation treatment on the occasion of the exhibition 'Lübeck 1500 - Kunstmetropole im Ostseeraum'

tests.text:
- the dimensions of the panel are 39 x 51.5 x c. 0.5 cm;it is  probably made of oak wood. The panel consists of two vertically alligned planks, the join runs along the centre. The panel has been trimmed on all four sides; at the right and left edges the pictorial space has been cropped. 
The original panel was probably thinned before it was attached to a plywood board, which extends 3-5 mm at the top and 2-5 mm at the bottom of the original panel. This treatment has made it difficult to establish the techniques employed to construct the panel.

- a chalk/glue based ground was applied to the support 
- the original edge of the the pictorial plane haas been retained in the form of a barbe along the top and lower edges (partially concealed by fill material; the left and right edges have been trimmed. The edge of the wooden panel was originally unpainted.
[unpublished conservation report, Maire Müller-Andrae von Butt, 2015]
